clinical_study.brief_title: Characterising Arm Recovery in People With Severe Stroke
clinical_study.official_title: Characterising Arm Recovery in People With Severe Stroke

brief_summary.textblock: The main goal of this program of research is to advance our understanding of how the severely damaged brain changes over the first 12-months post stroke. The investigators will determine 'who recovers', 'who does not recover', and 'why'

detailed_description.textblock: The main goal of this program of research is to advance our understanding of how the severely damaged brain changes over the first 12-months post stroke. The prevalence and severity of stroke related arm disability is increasing and the prospect of optimal recovery is poor. Studies have demonstrated that stroke survivors with severe disability lack early indicators (<7-days to <1-month post-stroke) of a good prognosis, such as active movement at the shoulder and wrist and integrity of the corticospinal tract. This has propagated the clinical belief that this cohort are unlikely to functionally benefit from rehabilitation efforts. However, it is possible that indicators of potential for recovery - either neuroanatomical or clinical - may present in individuals with severe stroke later, that is beyond the early time-period. Indeed, there is increasing evidence of the potential for ongoing improvements in motor performance in response to intensive interventions that are undertaken 6-months or more post-stroke. This therefore, implies that there is some degree of untapped recovery potential. However, as very few studies have longitudinally explored the potential indicators of recovery in a severe cohort, the dynamic capacity of the severely damaged remains unknown. Thus, there is a need to determine 'who recovers', 'who does not recover', and 'why' to be able to promote optimal arm recovery in people with severe impairment after stroke. We will assess stroke survivors <4-weeks, 3-months, 6-months and 12-months post stroke using a range of neuroimaging and clinical outcome measures. The findings from this study will build the foundations for more personalized health care options for people with severe arm impairment post stroke.

primary_outcome.description: Determine the structural and functional connectivity of the brain using diffusion weighted imaging, resting state-functional magnetic resonance imaging and myelin water fraction imaging.

secondary_outcome.measure: REACH (Rating of Everyday Arm Use in the Community and Home)
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report measure of everyday arm use
Measurement of real world arm use (activity count) over a 7-day period at each time frame

secondary_outcome.measure: PASS (Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke patients)
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of balance (static and dynamic) and lower limb functional tasks
Measurement of cognitive impairment after stroke
Dose in minutes of passive, active, functional or sensory upper limb tasks performed over a 7-day period at each time frame

secondary_outcome.measure: National Institute of Stroke Severity Scale

secondary_outcome.description: Determine the myelin content within the brain
Explore the stroke survivor's perception of meaningful recovery of their upper limb

arm_group.description: Stroke survivors with subacute and severe upper limb disability

intervention.description: Stroke survivors will be assessed at four time frames post stroke to evaluate neuroplastic and clinical changes in arm recovery over the first 12-months post stroke.

study_pop.textblock: Stroke survivors with subacute and severe upper limb disability will be evaluated longitudinally.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adults aged 18 to 90 years;
- sustained their first stroke;
- demonstrate subacute (<1 month) and severe upper limb motor deficits (defined by a SAFE [shoulder abduction and finger extension] score of <5 out of 10 points); and
- can follow single stage commands
Exclusion Criteria:
- neurological condition other than stroke e.g., Parkinson's disease
